Patterns & Practices and ALT.NET – The Software Factories are Important

Posted by davidhayden on November 1, 2007

I was pondering the Do’s and Don’ts list yesterday that Glenn Block posted on his blog, and couldn’t help but think that for the most part the Patterns & Practices Team is already doing the Do’s and not doing the Don’ts.


As someone who has spent the past year consuming, consulting, and presenting on p&p topics, I can assure you that the various software factories and guidance bundles coming out of p&p are critical to helping .NET developers transition to proven practices. The software factories / guidance bundles allow new developers to quickly and productively see the value of various proven practices that are not easy to grasp and implement otherwise. The software factories are not perfect and are not appropriate for all situations, but the factories use of




  • Intelligent code generation for productive implementation of proven practices,


  • Guidance that discusses software patterns and proven practices and when and when not to use them,


  • Documentation that mentions key scenarios and when and when to use the software factories,


  • Guidance that discusses alternate choices at times, often OSS alternatives, to what is provided in the factories, and


  • Reference implementations to show more complex “real-world” use of the factories and proven practices

are critical to giving developers a more complete and thorough understanding of the topics as well as making the use of proven practices more inviting when first starting out. You rarely find this reinforcement of guidance out in the wild that helps developers understand and appreciate the proven practices using different approaches and media


Based on giving a lot of presentations at CodeCamps and .NET Developer Groups, I can attest it is the productivity benefits of the software factories from within Visual Studio that many times initially draw developers to proven practices. It is the software factories that get them hooked, seeking additional guidance and alternative solutions later on, much of what is discussed in communities like ALT.NET. Take away the software factories and guidance bundles and you lose a major pathway to developer enlightment IMHO.

This entry was posted in Uncategorized. Bookmark the permalink. Follow any comments here with the RSS feed for this post.

7 Responses to Patterns & Practices and ALT.NET – The Software Factories are Important

  1. David Hayden says:
    November 2, 2007 at 4:06 pm

    Jeremy, I am disappointed I couldn’t make it to DevTeach and meet you as well. I am hoping the next MVP Summit or maybe the next DevTeach if I get the chance to present again.

  2. David Hayden says:
    November 2, 2007 at 3:56 pm

    Jeremy,

    I think you may have misunderstood me. I am not advocating using software factories without understanding design principles. I am suggesting that having software productivity tools, like software factories and ReSharper, help and encourage people to actually use and implement design principles in the real world.

    P&P has been educating people on software patterns, design principles, and proven practices for quite some time. And the documentation that goes along with the software factories spends an incredible amount of time on the proven practices, patterns, their origins, why you would and would not use them, etc.

    What is nice about the software factories is that they encourage the use of the proven practices in real-world development from within the IDE, which in many cases gets new developers to actually use the proven practices. It is often that productive guidance from within the IDE which hooks people into using the patterns. I realize this is not the case for everyone, but there are a lot of developers that migrate to proven practices for that very reason. I meet them all the time at .NET Developer Groups and CodeCamps.

    Experienced developers like Scott and yourself may not need this level of assistance, but don’t confuse that with there is no need or it is not important.

  3. Jeremy D. Miller says:
    November 2, 2007 at 3:25 pm

    David,

    I’m going to disagree with you as well. I think the design principles are far more important to learn than memorizing the wizard screens in a Software Factory. Whether or not the Software Factories are a good design or not is an orthogonal discussion. The question on the table is how best to teach developers good practices.

    I think it’s far more effective for developers to have a good grasp of the design fundamentals before picking up one of the factories. The best way to be effective with any tool or framework is to understand “why” it’s built the way that it is. Even using a software factory you’re still likely to create bad code if you’re a bad coder.

    If your first exposure to MVP or Separation of Concerns or Dependency Injection is inside one of these Software Factories I think there’s a very high probability that you’ll miss the concepts. When you’re learning one of these factories I think the natural focus is going to be on learning the mechanics of the factory and tooling. One of our problems in the .Net community is the overemphasis on learning API’s, libraries, and tricks instead of principles. I think the factories will just continue this problem, even if they’re built along better lines of thought.

    Building Software Factories is fine and all, but I’d still like to see the P&P team put a stronger emphasis on teaching design and coding principles with .Net tooling first. I don’t share your opinion that the factories are a good tool for teaching.

    I *was* looking forward to talking to you about this at DevTeach and I’m disappointed that you’re not going to be there. Hope to catch up to you some other time.

    Jeremy

  4. David Hayden says:
    November 2, 2007 at 3:08 pm

    Scott,

    But the tools do reinforce proven practices as well as discuss the origins of those proven practices, key scenarios ( based on customer demand from real developers working on real problems and real projects ) as to when and when not to use the guidance and factories, alternative solutions, and numerous examples and reference implementations showing the guidance for one to decide if it is right for their situations.

    P&P is not claiming to be the best solution, only solution, or even a viable solution in all cases and they are quite upfront in their documentation, examples, etc. And, many of the developers in the p&p community have real world experience with both the p&p tools AND competing tools coming out of other communities, providing a very trusted and unbiased opinion on strengths and weaknesses. I considered myself a good example, here, because my posts show both the positives and weaknesses of all p&p solutions as well as discuss alternative tools used by communities, like ALT.NET. Sam Gentile was also a great example and I was sorry to see him go.

    Given all that and the fact that the guidance offers a lot of productivity benefits from within the customers IDE of choice, Visual Studio, you have a wonderful path for developers to become more familiar with proven practices. As they gain confidence and experience, they will feel better about using other tools given the new knowledge.

    Certainly, one doesn’t have to choose this path and it may not be the most direct path depending on your needs, but it is a good option for those developers and work environments that feel more comfortable taking this path. I love the diversity, here too, so yeah, the software factories are a good thing.

    I appreciate your comment. Thanks.

  5. ScottBellware says:
    November 1, 2007 at 11:39 pm

    > Software factories are a newer strategy and quite effective as one gets the immediate benefits of
    > productivity of implementing proven practices during development.

    Except when the tools reinforce not-so-proven practices by delivering them to the community via Microsoft’s authoritative voice as defacto proven practices.

    I wouldn’t say that a developer can’t learn from P&P tools, but I think they can learn a lot more from tools that fall out of communities that are still actively engaged in application development and are working toward the resolution of tangible, intimate pain points.

    What would it mean if some P&P’s tools didn’t in fact represent or reinforce the practices and values as well as alternatives that have been vetted by larger communities through a tangible experience-driven design process?

    Tooling and practices are about making the best choice. I’ve heard doubt about some of P&P’s tools even from people within P&P. In that case, it’s ethically-corrupt to represent any lessor tool except with absolute honesty as to its weaknesses, and to point developers to better and best options.

    Diversity is a great thing, and P&P contributes to that greatness, but P&P as a body within Microsoft Corp. can’t always afford to be honest with its audience, and this is part of what tarnishes its rep in the alt.net community.

    The principles – and their ever-evolving nature – come from experience on day-to-day, month-after-month real world projects. P&P is a tools organization that has much less call and motivation to return to the real world and get a finely-honed sense for the pain points. If they did – if P&P operated like a work-study program or an open source lab… well, then we’d be talking about a whole other level of greatness.

  6. David Hayden says:
    November 1, 2007 at 5:49 pm

    I agree with that Glenn. I don’t think they have really been an end goal, however, but just a part of the p&p strategy to reinforce proven practices in many ways to best speak to the developer. IMHO, the software factories are one of the more recent strategies that you guys have employed in educating the developer. Blue books, reference implementations, webcasts, and other guidance has been around for quite some time from p&p and you never stopped doing it. Software factories are a newer strategy and quite effective as one gets the immediate benefits of productivity of implementing proven practices during development.

  7. Glenn Block says:
    November 1, 2007 at 5:37 pm

    The takeaway that I heard was rather than focusing on tools, focus on the principles behind the tools and examples of how to implement those principles using the platform. Tools are transient, but the principles are not. I thnk we need to strike a balance here. Software Factories have been tremendously valuable so I would not vote to get rid of them. However in the future I’d like to see them fall out after the fact rather than being the end goal. This offers the benefit of allowing people to pick and choose.
